title: The pipe
text:
Summary
This session you have:

Learnt R basic syntax
Learnt how to transform your data
Written concise code that is easy to follow

title: From Surveys to Populations
text:
Surveys

Populations are very difficult to collect data on

Even the census misses people!

Happily, we can use surveys of a sample of our population to learn things about our population
However, our ability to do this is conditional on how good our sample is
What do I mean by “good”?

title: From Surveys to Populations
text:
The 2024 US Presidential Election

Elections are preceded by a flood of surveys

title: From Surveys to Populations
text:
Surveys

Surveys are conducted on a subset (sample) of the population of interest
Our population of interest: individuals who voted in the 2024 US Presidential Election

title: From Surveys to Populations
text:
A good sample

A good sample is a representative one
How closely does our sample reflect our population

title: From Surveys to Populations
text:
Parallel worlds

Remember back to last session on experiments
In an ideal world, we would be able to create two parallel worlds (one with the treatment, one held as our control)

One version of the election booth run without monitors (the control)
One version with monitors (the treatment)

These worlds are perfectly identical to each other prior to treatment
We cannot do this :(

title: From Surveys to Populations
text:
The next best thing

Our next best option is to create two groups that were as identical to one another as possible prior to treatment
If they are (almost) identical, differences between their group-wide outcomes can be attributed to the treatment
One good way of getting two (almost) identical groups is to assign individuals to those groups randomly

Think back to our 1,000 hypothetical people!

title: From Surveys to Populations
text:
Randomization

Randomization continues to pop its chaotic head up
We can use it to create a sample that is (almost) identical to our population, on average
Drawing randomly from our population increases our chances of ending up with a sample that reflects that population
This would be referred to as a representative sample

title: From Surveys to Populations
text:
Random sampling

All individuals in the population need to have an equal chance of being selected for the sample

If this holds, you have a pure random sample

This is really hard to do!

How likely were you to answer the pollster’s unknown number, calling you in the middle of the day?
Even if you did answer, how likely were you to answer all their questions?

title: From Surveys to Populations
text:
To illustrate
Countries’ GDP in 2022:

title: From Surveys to Populations
text:
Countries’ GDP
I want to estimate the average GDP across all countries in 2022.

I send out a survey to all countries’ Departments of Statistics and ask for their GDP figures for 2022.
I get 60 responses:


sample_df <- gdp_df |> 
  drop_na(sample_value) |> 
  sample_n(size = 60) |> 
  transmute(country, gdp = sample_value)

sample_df

# A tibble: 60 × 2
   country                gdp
   <chr>                <dbl>
 1 San Marino         1.83e 9
 2 Iran, Islamic Rep. 3.94e11
 3 Barbados           6.26e 9
 4 Switzerland        8.18e11
 5 Spain              1.45e12
 6 Uzbekistan         9.01e10
 7 Norway             5.94e11
 8 Gambia, The        2.20e 9
 9 Tanzania           7.58e10
10 Nicaragua          1.56e10
# ℹ 50 more rows

title: From Surveys to Populations
text:
Countries’ GDP
I now calculate the average of these responses, which I find to be:

sample_df |> 
  summarise(avg_gdp = scales::dollar(mean(gdp, na.rm = T)))

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  avg_gdp         
  <chr>           
1 $299,399,082,460


Now, imagine that we knew definitively that it was NA. Why such a large difference?

title: From Surveys to Populations
text:
Non-response bias
Poorer countries are far less likely to be able or willing to provide these economic data to academics or international organizations.

They tend to be underrepresented in a lot of data

My sample was biased against poorer countries.

They were not equally likely to respond to my request for data as rich countries

title: From Surveys to Populations
text:
Large numbers

Randomization isn’t enough: we also need to draw a sufficiently large sample from our population

One person pulled randomly from the class isn’t going to be very reflective of the class!

title: Styling Your Plots
text:
Data visualization
We will use data visualization to answer the following question:

Do cars with big engines use more fuel than cars with small engines?

title: Styling Your Plots
text:
Add useful titles and labels

ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) + 
  geom_point(mapping = aes(colour = class)) + 
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") + 
  labs(
    title = "Engine displacement and highway miles per gallon",
    subtitle = "Values for seven different classes of cars",
    x = "Engine displacement (L)",
    y = "Highway miles per gallon"
  )

title: Styling Your Plots
text: Add useful titles and labels

title: Styling Your Plots
text:
Flexible visualization
You can use visual elements to communicate your findings in engaging ways.

ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) + 
  geom_point(mapping = aes(color = class == "2seater")) + 
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") + 
  labs(
    title = "Engine displacement and highway miles per gallon",
    subtitle = "Values for seven different classes of cars",
    x = "Engine displacement (L)",
    y = "Highway miles per gallon"
  )

title: Styling Your Plots
section: Changing the look of your plots
text:
Changing the look of your plots

ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) + 
  geom_point(colour = "pink") + 
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") + 
  labs(
    title = "Engine displacement and highway miles per gallon",
    subtitle = "Values for seven different classes of cars",
    x = "Engine displacement (L)",
    y = "Highway miles per gallon"
  )

title: Styling Your Plots
text:
Let’s clean our graph up
Less is more when it comes to data visualization.

ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) + 
  geom_point(mapping = aes(colour = class)) + 
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  labs(
    title = "Engine displacement and highway miles per gallon",
    subtitle = "Values for seven different classes of cars",
    x = "Engine displacement (L)",
    y = "Highway miles per gallon"
  ) 



All pre-set ggplot themes can be found in the ggplot documentation.

title: Styling Your Plots
text: Let’s clean this up

title: Styling Your Plots
text:
Creating your own theme

ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) + 
  geom_point(mapping = aes(colour = class)) + 
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") + 
  theme(
    legend.position = "bottom",
    panel.grid = element_blank(),
    panel.background = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot",
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold")
  ) + 
  labs(
    title = "Engine displacement and highway miles per gallon",
    subtitle = "Values for seven different classes of cars",
    x = "Engine displacement (L)",
    y = "Highway miles per gallon"
  ) 



All theme elements that you can control can be found in the ggplot documentation. There are a lot!

title: Loading and Exploring Your Data
text:
The mpg data set
A couple of useful variables:

displ: engine displacement, in liters
hwy: highway miles per gallon

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
text:
Causes and effects
Our goal is to better understand what factors lead to certain outcomes of interest.

Does increasing the number of voting booths close to a potential voter make that person more likely to vote?
Do peace treaties signed with factionalized rebel groups more often lead to a return to conflict than those signed with a single, cohesive group?
Does trade between two countries make war between them less likely?

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
text:
Causes and effects
These are causal statements:

More local voting booths \(\rightarrow\) More likely to vote
More factionalization \(\rightarrow\) More likely to restart conflict
Trade \(\rightarrow\) Less likely to go to war

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
section: How to identify causes and their effects
text:
How to identify causes and their effects
Proving that changes to one factor cause changes to another is very tricky!

Need to account for all the other factors

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
section: The efficacy of international election monitors
text:
The efficacy of international election monitors
Do international monitors cause less election-day fraud in democratic elections?

Number of elections monitored by international observers exploded throughout the 2000s
But do monitors increase the chances the election will be free and fair?
In other words, are they effective?



Hyde, Susan D. 2007. “The Observer Effect in International Politics: Evidence from a Natural Experiment.” World Politics 60 (1): 37–63. http://www.jstor.org/stable/40060180.

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
section: The efficacy of international election monitors
text:
The efficacy of international election monitors
Dr Susan Hyde set out to answer this very question. From her article (page 39):

If the presence of international observers causes a reduction in election-day fraud, the effect of observers should be visible at the subnational level by comparing polling stations that were visited by observers with those that were not visited. More specifically, if international monitoring reduces electionday fraud directly, all else held equal, the cheating parties should gain less of their ill-gotten vote share in polling stations that were visited by international monitors.

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
text:
Causal relationships
Refers to the directional connection between a change in one variable and a corresponding change in another.

The direction matters!
Treatment variable: the variable causing changes to another variable.
Outcome variable: the variable changing as a result of changes to another variable (the treatment).

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
text:
Treatment and outcome variables
We want to test whether the presence of international monitors (treatment) leads to less election day fraud (outcome).
International election monitors present at polling stations \(\rightarrow\) Less election-day fraud at that station

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
text:
Treatment variable
At any given polling station in any given election, monitors may be: 1) present, or 2) not present.
Two different conditions:

Treatment: condition with treatment (monitors are present)
Control: condition without treatment (monitors are not present)



Treatment variables do not need to be binary.

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
text:
Outcome variable
At any given polling station in any given election, fraud may: 1) occur, or 2) not occur.


Outcome variables also do not need to binary.

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
text:
Observing our outcome
Sometimes it can be hard to observe our outcome of interest.

How might we see all election-day fraud?
How might we measure it?

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
text:
Observing our outcome
Hyde’s answer: vote-share!
International election monitors present at polling stations \(\rightarrow\) Less election-day fraud at that station \(\rightarrow\) Lower vote-share for the cheating party

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
text:
Individual causal effects
We want to know whether the treatment causes a change in our outcome of interest.
What might this look like in the real world?

Imagine we are looking at a specific election
Five polling stations

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
section: How on Earth does this work so well?
text:
How on Earth does this work so well?
Randomization!

Monitors were assigned to polling stations randomly (for example, with the flip of a coin)
This created two groups of stations that were roughly identical on average to one another prior to treatment
This mimics what happens when we split our world into two (creating two literally identical groups)

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
text:
Our goal
We want two groups that are completely identical to one another prior to treatment.

This allows us to compare their outcomes after treatment and claim that the treatment caused differences in those outcomes (if any differences exist)

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
text: Our goal

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
text:
Next best thing
Instead, we should try to make two groups that are as similar as possible to each other prior to treatment.

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
text:
The magic of randomization
Perfectly random assignment does this very well!

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
section: Don’t take my word for it
text:
Don’t take my word for it
Imagine we have a group of 1,000 individuals. We know the following about them:

Height
Weight
Eye colour

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
text:
How similar are these groups?
Let’s first check their heights:

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
text:
How similar are these groups?
And their weights:

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
text:
How similar are these groups?
And their eye colors:

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
section: Making sure this wasn’t a fluke

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
text: Check how similar they are

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
text:
Increasingly similar
In fact, if we did this many, many, many times, these groups would be, on average, increasingly identical!
Why?

Central limit theorem
Law of large numbers



We will talk more about those concepts later in the course.

title: Causal Effects and Experiments
section: Do international monitors deter election-day fraud?
text:
Do international monitors deter election-day fraud?
Yes!

The international community monitored the 2003 Armenian Presidential elections
Monitors were assigned randomly to the polling stations
Hyde found a big average difference between the vote share received by the cheating party at monitored stations compared to non-monitored stations.

title: Data Visualization
text:
Data visualization
We will use data visualization to answer the following question:

Do cars with big engines use more fuel than cars with small engines?

title: Data Visualization
text:
EXERCISE

What do you think is the answer to this question?



How would you prove your answer? What information about cars would you need?

title: Data Visualization
text:
R4DS
This session will borrow (read: steal) heavily from Hadley Wickham’s R for Data Science book.

Source: R4DS

title: Data Visualization
text:
Data visualization: a critical skill

You can learn an incredible amount about your data from plotting it
Easier to digest the vast amount of information required to do data analysis from a plot than raw numbers

title: Data Visualization
text: Skipping to the end

title: Data Visualization
text:
How did we do this?

ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) + 
  geom_point(mapping = aes(colour = class)) + 
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") + 
  theme(
    legend.position = "bottom",
    panel.grid = element_blank(),
    panel.background = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot",
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold")
  ) + 
  labs(
    title = "Engine displacement and highway miles per gallon",
    subtitle = "Values for seven different classes of cars",
    x = "Engine displacement (L)",
    y = "Highway miles per gallon"
  )









We will step through this now. By the end of this session, you will be able to make your own colourful data visualisations using R.

title: Working with Categorical Data
text:
Working with categorical data
We often want to explore patterns in categorical (or discrete) data. We need new tools to do this.

title: Working with Categorical Data
text:
Working with categorical data

select(mpg, manufacturer, model, drv)

text:
Visualizing distributions

ggplot(mpg, aes(x = drv)) + 
  geom_bar()

text:
Visualizing distributions
Reorder in relation to frequency

ggplot(mpg, aes(x = fct_infreq(drv))) +
  geom_bar()

title: Working with Categorical Data
text:
Visualizing numeric variables

ggplot(mpg, aes(x = hwy)) +
  geom_histogram()
